0743DAB200A342CC972EF033CAB280F8.description: Describe daily events as occurring yesterday, today, or tomorrow.

CFF86FCBF260451F8FB36C466F94A8E6.description: Sequence events, limited to two events, according to time using words or ordinal numbers.

067DCC3446504E14BB2549A3334D5239.description: Time can be perceived as a sequence.

48781D92560F42329D29AEBB6FE388CB.description: Sequence in time can be described in words, such as first, next and today.

937A6A3961D04B0DA65B00F0FED52EAA.description: Children interpret time as a sequence of events.

1A2FEAD190974DBF9F0EC92BBFA820F7.description: Time: Duration is described and quantified by time.

A03167C7FE484D1F8BA4BB9571BB080E.description: Create a repeating pattern with up to three repeating elements.

46AB0E190C4842E6AF96D55D4CC583A6.description: Predict the next elements in a repeating pattern.

8A6F83C3276E4A7887580CE22068F2F2.description: Recognize change or constancy between elements in a repeating pattern.

F634FFBA31A04041B3CF3039AAC48752.description: Recognize repeating patterns encountered in daily routines and play, including songs or dances.

5E62B389F22744579500892E134910C3.description: A pattern is characterized by how the elements change or remain constant.

70C791B41AAD4465A1650510FF1EB26B.description: Repeating patterns have one or more elements that repeat.

B699815146124031BF9BA6CEFAE7049A.description: A pattern can involve elements such as sounds, objects, pictures, symbols and actions.

4B179CAD112245B9963FC572C489FF21.description: Children identify and create repeating patterns.

B20B615231E248B08AEF5B74603064D2.description: Patterns: Awareness of patterns supports problem solving in various situations.

CADA13178AD24DEDB1644F0323606A0D.description: Describe the size of an object in relation to a purpose or need, using comparative language.

431F3B6CB76145F19C129AC3B2B8837B.description: Describe the size of an object in relation to another object, using comparative language.

AD27B5DE6DAE461BB60BC1A54E1442AA.description: Compare the length, area, weight, or capacity of two objects directly.

55A0FDE94F764642BFBF2F18332A3A5B.description: Identify measurable attributes of familiar objects to which size may refer.

A1FC2378912C4C23BB36DA04103D7CC8.description: The size of an object can be described in relation to a purpose or need.

0DA62AF7643348A1981C2825040B93D0.description: The size of two objects can be compared directly.

A698A9B109A34B49976660CC2DB12CF8.description: Size may refer to only one measurable attribute at a time.

B217B86E36D647169CDE7C0ED83D7502.description: Size describes the amount of one measurable attribute of an object or a space.

8511887B638F4FC2886CB0046FC00A42.description: Comparisons of size can be described by using words such as longer, shorter, heavier, lighter, too big and too small.

2C4BCB202C234732A4FFF5A920A4326C.description: Size can be interpreted in many ways (according to measurable attributes), such as: the length of an object, how much, flat space an object covers (area), how much a container holds (capacity) and the heaviness of an object (weight).

37D6A492A78F487394658C6B1D152E93.description: Children explore size through direct comparison.

84D747813E074C77AEA8F1E360C0A576.description: Measurement: Attributes such as length, area, volume, and angle are quantified by measurement.

9EC7314F36084ED0BF5EE074BDB82987.description: Describe a shape using words such as flat, curved, straight, or round.

D787DD11812E4C17969CA58DA08DB157.description: Investigate three-dimensional shapes by rolling, stacking, or sliding.

AB5657B4E5B9435A8770C24E39C73272.description: Identify familiar two- and three-dimensional shapes.

FFF350225D6B49A497BD0A99263D805B.description: Relate shapes in nature to various two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes.

CB82C822D6354A458D64C84550DCA88A.description: Shape is structured two-dimensional or three-dimensional space.

8AAE26650BA443F89E2DFE964946164B.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit relate specific shapes to those found in nature.

166C6299C6C24B66A7313142D7FCFA9C.description: Familiar two- and three-dimensional shapes can be found in nature, such as circles, triangles, cubes and cylinders.

324D564B76CD41B7841ACED6C444E1C7.description: A shape can be represented using objects, pictures, or words.

5240180063D34CAD8C365DDF7A898705.description: Geometry: Shapes are defined and related by geometric attributes.

E7A496B2A2C74AB78075C837F7FCB943.description: Recognize various ways to make 5 and 10.

43029F9E1D9D4E379566B9F4BE541AF2.description: Identify a quantity in various groups or arrangements.

44DAE07EFF90444A944ACF89A123D695.description: A quantity remains the same no matter how the objects are grouped or arranged (counting principle: conservation).

6C4A940CC24C42B987CAE89FBF166F25.description: Quantity can be arranged in various ways.

2F1CC80189A341F19471428AB09D9F70.description: Children interpret compositions of quantities within 10.

9ADA9748900E4E8596B2B2F19093C97A.description: Solve problems in familiar situations by counting.

5F9F860050944759A4C981B4FA28916F.description: Describe a quantity in relation to a purpose or need using comparative language.

88A4E853FF714D18B35BD51DD8394AB2.description: Describe quantities relative to each other using comparative language.

0E0CF8A0BCDD4CCC8F7ACDD6996523FE.description: Compare the size of two sets using one-to-one correspondence.

C57D075F6AB0488980E927CD5D00BA85.description: Count within 10, forward and backward, starting at any number, according to the counting principles.

159727D5955A4526A61485F6D1E43156.description: Relate a numeral to a specific quantity.

4235299A76D849B2BC829E089E3862A8.description: Represent a quantity in different ways.

CCBFFBA4797E49D5B3C6610B5C33FE64.description: Recognize a number of familiar objects as a quantity.

1F241B19B2414A02ADDF763E3EB551A4.description: A quantity can be described in relation to a purpose or need.

1D19617851894C76AD4B771CB184B74E.description: A quantity can be described relative to another quantity.

C4ABF4C3954B414EA41A79D70BFA3854.description: Quantity can be determined without counting.

256F610D5BC147A1BC61BDB522C746BE.description: Any quantity of like or unlike objects can be counted as a set (counting principle: abstraction).

3DADDE3FEADD42AB97059191DA29D699.description: The last number used to count represents the quantity (counting principle: cardinality).

856414C759464745B6A744B49473D4C7.description: A quantity can be determined by counting each object in a set once and only once (counting principle: one-to-one correspondence).

01CD4C9CCAD047DAB27F2D59B24B0D95.description: A quantity remains the same no matter the order in which the objects are counted (counting principle: order irrelevance).

FEF277D90BB34B10A2F611FF7D51EFFF.description: A quantity is always counted using the same sequence of words (counting principle: stable order).

1D457FE763AE42E98FAFA9D8211A797D.description: Quantity can be the number of objects in a set.

D27BE1CEADC74F109D2F7F139350B3EF.description: Comparisons of quantity can be described by using words such as more, less, same, enough and not enough.

E977BCB2CE7B496981C80C94FB31229E.description: A small quantity can be recognized at a glance (subitized).

3D4EC04DA23B457A9EC83534DD1BBB74.description: Quantity can be determined by counting.

D64F3E8F6FB144E8A5DC423E4BAF6DE5.description: Quantity can be represented using objects, pictures, words and numerals.

7F678668CAD6417B85AC5EB404076C78.description: Number: Quantity is measured with numbers that enable counting, labelling, comparing, and operating.
